Name: Formal Process For Approving and Testing Configuration Changes
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following: 
A formal process for approving and testing all network connections and changes to the firewall and router configurations.

Name: Network Diagram
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following:  
A current network diagram that documents all connections between the cardholder data environment and other networks, including any wireless networks.

Name: Process to Keep Diagram Current
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following:  
A process to ensure the network diagram is kept current.

Name: Cardholder Data Flow Diagram
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following: 
A current diagram that shows all cardholder data flows across systems and networks.

Name: Cardholder Data Flow Diagram - Kept current
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following:  
A process to ensure the network diagram is kept current.

Name: Firewall Required
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following:  
A firewall shall be required and implemented at each Internet connection and between any demilitarized zone (DMZ) and the internal network zone.

Name: Diagram Consistent with Firewall Configuration Standards
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following:  
The current network diagram shall be consistent with the firewall configuration standards.

Name: Groups, Roles, and Responsibilities
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following:  
Groups, roles, and responsibilities for logical management of network components shall be assigned and documented in the firewall and router configuration standards.

Name: Documented List of Services
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following:  
Firewall and router configuration standards shall include a documented list of services, protocols, and ports, including business justification and approval for each.

Name: Insecure Services, Protocols, and Ports Identified
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following:  
All insecure services, protocols, and ports shall be identified, and security features shall be documented and implemented for each identified service.

Name: Firewall and Configuration Review
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following:  
Firewall and router configuration standards require review of firewall and router rule sets at least every six months.

Name: Firewall and Configuration Review - Six Months
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configuration standards are established and implemented to include the following: 
Firewall and router rule sets shall be reviewed at least every six months.

Name: Inbound and Outbound Traffic Restricted
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configurations restrict connections between untrusted networks and any system in the cardholder data environment as follows: 
Inbound and outbound traffic shall be restricted to that which is necessary for the cardholder data environment.
 
 Note: An "untrusted network" is any network that is external to the networks belonging to the entity under review, and/or which is out of the entity's ability to control or manage.

Name: All Other Traffic Denied
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configurations restrict connections between untrusted networks and any system in the cardholder data environment as follows: 
All other inbound and outbound traffic shall be specifically denied (for example by using an explicit "deny all" or an implicit deny after allow statement). 
 Note: An "untrusted network" is any network that is external to the networks belonging to the entity under review, and/or which is out of the entity's ability to control or manage.

Name: Router Configuration Files
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configurations restrict connections between untrusted networks and any system in the cardholder data environment as follows: 
Router configuration files shall be secured from unauthorized access and synchronized, for example, the running (or active) configuration matches the startup configuration (used when machines are booted). 
 
 Note: An "untrusted network" is any network that is external to the networks belonging to the entity under review, and/or which is out of the entity's ability to control or manage.

Name: Firewalls Installed Between Wireless Networks and Cardholder Data Environment
Description:
Ensure that the firewall and router configurations restrict connections between untrusted networks and any system in the cardholder data environment as follows: 
Perimeter firewalls shall be installed between all wireless networks and the cardholder data environment, and these firewalls shall be configured to deny or, if traffic is necessary for business purposes, permit only authorized traffic between the wireless environment and the cardholder data environment. 
 
 Note: An "untrusted network" is any network that is external to the networks belonging to the entity under review, and/or which is out of the entity's ability to control or manage.

Name: Implement a DMZ
Description:
Direct public access shall be prohibited between the Internet and any system component in the cardholder data environment, as follows: 
A DMZ shall be implemented to limit inbound traffic to only system components that provide authorized publicly accessible services, protocols, and ports.

Name: Limit inbound traffic
Description:
Direct public access shall be prohibited between the Internet and any system component in the cardholder data environment, as follows: 
Inbound Internet traffic shall be limited to IP addresses within the DMZ.

Name: Anti-Spoofing
Description:
Direct public access shall be prohibited between the Internet and any system component in the cardholder data environment, as follows: 
Anti-spoofing measures shall be implemented to detect and block forged sourced IP addresses from entering the network.
 
 (For example, block traffic originating from the internet with an internal address)

Name: No Unauthorized Outbound Traffic
Description:
Direct public access shall be prohibited between the Internet and any system component in the cardholder data environment, as follows: 
Outbound traffic from the cardholder data environment to the Internet shall be explicitly authorized.

Name: Implement Stateful Inspection
Description:
Direct public access shall be prohibited between the Internet and any system component in the cardholder data environment, as follows: 
Only established connections shall be permitted into the network.

Name: Cardholder Data Segregated
Description:
Direct public access shall be prohibited between the Internet and any system component in the cardholder data environment, as follows: 
System components that store cardholder data (such as a database) placed in an internal network zone, shall be segregated from the DMZ and other untrusted networks.

Name: Private IP Address and Routing Information
Description:
Direct public access shall be prohibited between the Internet and any system component in the cardholder data environment, as follows: 
Methods shall be in place to prevent the disclosure of private IP addresses and routing information to the Internet: 
 
 Note: Methods to obscure IP addressing may include, but are not limited to: 
 - Network Address Translation (NAT) 
 - Placing servers containing cardholder data behind proxy servers/firewalls, 
 - Removal or filtering of route advertisements for private networks that employ registered addressing, Internal use of RFC1918 address space instead of registered addresses

Name: Private IP Address and Routing Information - Authorizations
Description:
Direct public access shall be prohibited between the Internet and any system component in the cardholder data environment, as follows: 
Any disclosure of private IP addresses and routing information to external entities shall be authorized.

Name: Install Personal Firewall Software
Description: Personal firewall software (or equivalent functionality) shall be installed and active on any portable computing devices (including company and/or employee-owned) that connect to the Internet when outside the network (for example, laptops used by employees), and which are also used to access the CDE.

Name: Personal Firewall Software - Not Alterable
Description: Personal firewall software (or equivalent functionality) shall be configured to specific configuration settings, actively running, and not alterable by users of mobile and/or employee-owned devices.

Name: Security Policies for Managing Firewalls
Description:
Security policies and operational procedures for managing firewalls shall be: 
 
 - Documented 
 - In use 
 - Known to all affected parties.

Name: Vendor Supplied Defaults
Description:
The vendor-supplied defaults shall be always changed before installing a system on the network:
 
 This applies to ALL default passwords, including but not limited to those used by operating systems, software that rovides security services, application and system accounts, point-of-sale (POS) terminals, payment applications, Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) community strings, etc.).

Name: Unnecessary Default Accounts Removed or Disabled
Description: Unnecessary default accounts shall be removed or disabled before installing a system on the network.

Name: Encryption Keys Changed from Default
Description:
For wireless environments connected to the cardholder data environment or transmitting cardholder data, all wireless vendor defaults shall be changed at installations, as follows: 
Encryption keys shall be changed from default at installation, and changed anytime anyone with knowledge of the keys leaves the company or changes positions.

Name: Default SNMP Community Strings Changed
Description:
For wireless environments connected to the cardholder data environment or transmitting cardholder data, all wireless vendor defaults shall be changed at installations, as follows: 
Default SNMP community strings on wireless devices shall be changed at installation.

Name: Default Passwords on Access Points Changed
Description:
For wireless environments connected to the cardholder data environment or transmitting cardholder data, all wireless vendor defaults shall be changed at installations, as follows: 
Default passwords/passphrases on access points shall be changed at installation.

Name: Firmware on Wireless Devices Updated
Description:
For wireless environments connected to the cardholder data environment or transmitting cardholder data, all wireless vendor defaults shall be changed at installations, as follows: 
Firmware on wireless devices shall be updated to support strong encryption for authentication and transmission over wireless networks.

Name: Other Security-Related Wireless Vendor Defaults Changed
Description:
For wireless environments connected to the cardholder data environment or transmitting cardholder data, all wireless vendor defaults shall be changed at installations, as follows: 
Other security-related wireless vendor defaults shall be changed, if applicable.

Name: Develop Configuration Standards
Description:
Configuration standards shall be developed for all system components and they shall be consistent with industry-accepted system hardening standards. 
 
 Sources of industry-accepted system hardening standards may include, but are not limited to, SysAdmin Audit Network Security (SANS) Institute, National Institute of Standards Technology (NIST), International Organization for Standardization (ISO), and Center for Internet Security (CIS).

Name: Develop Configuration Standards - Updated as needed
Description: System configuration standards shall be updated as new vulnerability issues are identified, as defined in Requirement 6.1

Name: Develop Configuration Standards - Applied to new systems
Description: System configuration standards shall be applied when new systems are configured.

Name: Develop Configuration Standards - Checklist
Description:
System configuration standards shall include all of the following: 
 
 - Changing of all vendor-supplied defaults and elimination of unnecessary default accounts
 - Implementing only one primary function per server to prevent functions that require different security levels from co-existing on the same server
 - Enabling only necessary services, protocols, daemons, etc., as required for the function of the system
 - Implementing additional security features for any required services, protocols or daemons that are considered to be insecure
 - Configuring system security parameters to prevent misuse
 - Removing all unnecessary functionality, such as scripts, drivers, features, subsystems, file systems, and unnecessary web servers

Name: One Primary Function Per Server
Description:
Only one primary function shall be implemented per server, to prevent functions that require different security levels from coexisting on the same server.
 
 For example, web servers, database servers, and DNS should be implemented on separate servers.

Name: Virtualization Technologies
Description: If virtualization technologies are used, only one primary function shall be implemented per virtual system component or device.

Name: Enable Only Necessary Services
Description: Only necessary services, protocols, daemons, etc. shall be enabled as required for the function of the system (services and protocols not directly needed to perform the devices specified function are disabled).

Name: Enable Only Necessary Services - Documentation
Description: All enabled insecure services, daemons, or protocols shall be justified per documented configuration standards.

Name: Security Features for Required Services
Description: Additional security features shall be documented and implemented for any required services, protocols or daemons that are considered to be insecure.

Name: Configure System Security
Description: System administrators and/or personnel that configure system components shall be knowledgeable about common security parameter settings for those system components.

Name: Configure System Security - Common Settings
Description: Common system security parameters settings shall be included in the system configuration standards.

Name: Configure System Security - Set Appropriately
Description: Security parameter settings shall be set appropriately on system components.

Name: Remove Unnecessary Functionality
Description: All unnecessary functionality, such as scripts, drivers, features, subsystems, file systems, and unnecessary web servers shall be removed.

Name: Enabled Functions Documented
Description: Enabled functions shall be documented and support secure configuration.

Name: Documented Functions on Components
Description: Only documented functionality shall be present on system components.

Name: Encrypted Admin Access
Description:
Non-console administrative access shall be encrypted as follows: 
All non-console administrative access shall be encrypted with strong cryptography, and a strong encryption method shall be invoked before the administrator's password is requested.

Name: Prevent Telnet
Description:
Non-console administrative access shall be encrypted as follows: 
System services and parameter files shall be configured to prevent the use of Telnet and other insecure remote login commands.

Name: Interface Encryption
Description:
Non-console administrative access shall be encrypted as follows: 
Administrator access to web-based management interfaces shall be encrypted with strong cryptography.

Name: Industry Best Practices
Description:
Non-console administrative access shall be encrypted as follows: 
For the technology in use, strong cryptography shall be implemented according to industry best practice and/or vendor recommendations.

Name: Inventory Maintained
Description: An inventory shall be maintained for systems components that are in scope for PCI DSS, including a list of hardware and software components and a description of function/use for each.

Name: Inventory Up-to-date
Description: The documented system component inventory shall be kept current.

Name: Security Policies for Managing Vendor Defaults
Description:
Security policies and operational procedures for managing vendor defaults and other security parameters shall be: 
 
 - Documented 
 - In use 
 - Known to all affected parties.

Name: Shared Hosting Provider - System Configured to Protect Environment
Description:
If you are a shared hosting provider, the systems shall be configured to protect each entity's (the customers') hosted environment and cardholder data. 
 
 See Appendix A1: Additional PCI DSS Requirements for Shared Hosting Providers for specific requirements that must be met.

Name: Storage and Retention Timing
Description:
Data-retention and disposal policies, procedures, and processes shall be implemented as follows: 
Data storage amount and retention time limited to that required for legal, regulatory, and/or business requirements.

Name: Cardholder Data Deletion
Description:
Data-retention and disposal policies, procedures, and processes shall be implemented as follows: 
Defined processes shall be in place for securely deleting cardholder data when no longer needed for legal, regulatory, and/or business reasons.

Name: Retention Requirements
Description:
Data-retention and disposal policies, procedures, and processes shall be implemented as follows: 
Specific retention requirements for cardholder data. 
 
 For example, cardholder data needs to be held for X period for Y business reasons.

Name: Quarterly Process for Reviewing Retention
Description:
Data-retention and disposal policies, procedures, and processes shall be implemented as follows: 
A quarterly process for identifying and securely deleting stored cardholder data that exceeds defined retention requirements.

Name: Meet the Requirements for Retention
Description:
Data-retention and disposal policies, procedures, and processes shall be implemented as follows: 
All stored cardholder data shall meet the requirements defined in the data-retention policy.

Name: Business Justification for Storage
Description: For issuers and/or companies that support issuing services and store sensitive authentication data, there shall be a documented business justification for the storage of sensitive authentication data.

Name: Data Secured
Description: For issuers and/or companies that support issuing services and store sensitive authentication data, the data shall be secured.

Name: Sensitive Authentication Data After Authorization
Description: Sensitive authentication data shall be deleted or rendered unrecoverable upon completion of the authorization process.

Name: Full Contents Not Stored
Description:
All systems shall adhere to the following requirements regarding non-storage of sensitive authentication data after authorization (even if encrypted): 
The full contents of any track (from the magnetic stripe located on the back of a card, equivalent data contained on a chip, or elsewhere) shall not be stored after authorization. 
 
 This data is alternatively called full track, track, track 1, track 2, and magnetic-stripe data. 
 
 Note: In the normal course of business, the following data elements from the magnetic stripe may need to be retained: 
 - The cardholder's name, 
 - Primary account number (PAN), 
 - Expiration date, and 
 - Service code 
 
 To minimize risk, store only these data elements as needed for business.

Name: Code or Value Not Stored
Description:
All systems shall adhere to the following requirements regarding non-storage of sensitive authentication data after authorization (even if encrypted): 
The card verification code or value (three-digit or fourdigit number printed on the front or back of a payment card) shall not be stored after authorization.

Name: PIN Not Stored
Description:
All systems shall adhere to the following requirements regarding non-storage of sensitive authentication data after authorization (even if encrypted): 
The personal identification number (PIN) or the encrypted PIN block shall not be stored after authorization.

Name: PAN Masked When Displayed
Description:
The PAN shall be masked when displayed (the first six and last four digits are the maximum number of digits to be displayed) such that only personnel with a legitimate business need can see more than the first six/last four digits of the PAN. 
 
 Note: This requirement does not supersede stricter requirements in place for displays of cardholder data - for example, legal or payment card brand requirements for point-of-sale (POS) receipts.

Name: PAN Unreadable When Stored
Description:
PAN shall be rendered unreadable anywhere it is stored (including data repositories, portable digital media, backup media, and in audit logs), by using any of the following approaches:
 
 - One-way hashes based on strong cryptography (hash must be of the entire PAN) 
 - Truncation (hashing cannot be used to replace the truncated segment of PAN) 
 - Index tokens and pads (pads must be securely stored) 
 - Strong cryptography with associated key management processes and procedures. 
 
 Note: It is a relatively trivial effort for a malicious individual to reconstruct original PAN data if they have access to both the truncated and hashed version of a PAN. Where hashed and truncated versions of the same PAN are present in an entity's environment, additional controls must be in place to ensure that the hashed and truncated versions cannot be correlated to reconstruct the original PAN.

Name: Logical Access to Encrypted Files Managed
Description:
If disk encryption (rather than file- or column-level database encryption) is used, access shall be managed as follows: 
Logical access to encrypted file systems shall be managed separately and independently of native operating system authentication and access control mechanisms (for example, by not using local user account databases or general network login credentials).
 
 Note: This requirement applies in addition to all other PCI DSS encryption and key management requirements.

Name: Cryptographic Keys Stored Securely
Description:
If disk encryption (rather than file- or column-level database encryption) is used, access shall be managed as follows: 
Cryptographic keys shall be stored securely (for example, stored on removable media that is adequately protected with strong access controls).
 
 Note: This requirement applies in addition to all other PCI DSS encryption and key management requirements.

Name: Removable Media Encrypted
Description:
If disk encryption (rather than file- or column-level database encryption) is used, access shall be managed as follows: 
Cardholder data on removable media shall be encrypted wherever stored.  
 
 Note: If disk encryption is not used to encrypt removable media, the data stored on this media will need to be rendered unreadable through some other method. 
 
 Note: This requirement applies in addition to all other PCI DSS encryption and key management requirements.

Name: Document Cryptographic Architecture
Description:
Keys shall be used to secure stored cardholder data protected against disclosure and misuse as follows: 
A documented description of the cryptographic architecture shall be maintained that includes: (For service providers only)
 
 - Details of all algorithms, protocols, and keys used for the protection of cardholder data, including key strength and expiry date, 
 - Description of the key usage for each key, 
 - Inventory of any HSMs and other SCDs used for key management?

Name: Key Restrictions
Description:
Keys shall be used to secure stored cardholder data protected against disclosure and misuse as follows: 
Access to cryptographic keys shall be restricted to the fewest number of custodians necessary. 
 
 Note: This requirement applies to keys used to encrypt stored cardholder data, and also applies to key-encrypting keys used to protect data-encrypting keys. Such keyencrypting keys must be at least as strong as the dataencrypting key.

Name: Key Storage
Description:
Keys shall be used to secure stored cardholder data protected against disclosure and misuse as follows: 
Secret and private cryptographic keys shall be used to encrypt/decrypt cardholder data stored in one (or more) of the following forms at all times: 
 
 - Encrypted with a key-encrypting key that is at least as strong as the data-encrypting key, and that is stored separately from the data-encrypting key 
 - Within a secure cryptographic device (such as a hardware (host) security module (HSM) or PTSapproved point-of-interaction device) 
 - As at least two full-length key components or key shares, in accordance with an industry-accepted method. 
 
 Note: It is not required that public keys be stored in one of these forms.

Name: Storage Locations
Description:
Keys shall be used to secure stored cardholder data protected against disclosure and misuse as follows:  
Cryptographic keys shall be stored in the fewest possible locations.

Name: Key Management Policies and Procedures
Description: All key-management processes and procedures shall be fully documented and implemented for cryptographic keys used for encryption of cardholder data.

Name: Keys are Shared with Customers
Description: If keys are shared with customers for transmission or storage of cardholder data, documentation shall be provided to customers that includes guidance on how to securely transmit, store and update customers keys, in accordance with requirements 3.6.1 through 3.6.8 below.

Name: Strong Key Generation
Description:
Key-management processes and procedures shall be implemented to require the following: 
Cryptographic key procedures shall include the generation of strong cryptographic keys.

Name: Key Distribution
Description:
Key-management processes and procedures shall be implemented to require the following: 
Cryptographic key procedures shall include secure cryptographic key distribution.

Name: Procedures Define Key Storage
Description:
Key-management processes and procedures shall be implemented to require the following: 
Cryptographic key procedures shall include secure cryptographic key storage.

Name: Key Changes
Description:
Key-management processes and procedures shall be implemented to require the following: 
Cryptographic key procedures shall include cryptographic key changes for keys that have reached the end of their defined cryptoperiod (for example, after a defined period of time has passed and/or after a certain amount of cipher-text has been produced by a given key), as defined by the associated application vendor or key owner, and based on industry best practices and guidelines (for example, NIST Special Publication 800-57).

Name: Key Retirement or Replacement
Description:
Key-management processes and procedures shall be implemented to require the following: 
Cryptographic key procedures shall include retirement or replacement (for example, archiving, destruction, and/or revocation) of cryptographic keys when the integrity of the key has been weakened (for example, departure of an employee with knowledge of a cleartext key).

Name: Replacement of Compromised Keys
Description:
Key-management processes and procedures shall be implemented to require the following: 
Cryptographic key procedures shall include replacement of known or suspected compromised keys.

Name: Key Retention
Description:
Key-management processes and procedures shall be implemented to require the following: 
If retired or replaced cryptographic keys are retained, these keys shall only be used for decryption/verification purposes, and not used for encryption operations.

Name: Manual Clear-Text
Description:
Key-management processes and procedures shall be implemented to require the following: 
If manual clear-text key-management operations are used, cryptographic key procedures shall include split knowledge and dual control of cryptographic keys as follows: 
 
 - Split knowledge procedures shall require that key components are under the control of at least two people who only have knowledge of their own key component. 
 
 AND 
 
 - Dual control procedures shall require that at least two people are required to perform any key management operations and no one person has access to the authentication materials (for example, passwords or keys) of another. 
 
 Note: Examples of manual key management operations include, but are not limited to: key generation, transmission, loading, storage and destruction

Name: Prevention of Unauthorized Substitution
Description:
Key-management processes and procedures shall be implemented to require the following: 
Cryptographic key procedures shall include the prevention of unauthorized substitution of cryptographic keys.

Name: Key-Custodian Responsibilities
Description:
Key-management processes and procedures shall be implemented to require the following: 
Cryptographic key custodians shall be required to formally acknowledge (in writing or electronically) that they understand and accept their key-custodian responsibilities.

Name: Policies and Procedures for Protecting Data
Description:
Security policies and operational procedures for protecting stored cardholder data shall be: 
 
 - Documented 
 - In use 
 - Known to all affected parties.

Name: Use Strong Cryptography to Protect Cardholder Data
Description:
Strong cryptography and security protocols shall be used to safeguard sensitive cardholder data during transmission over open, public networks. 
 
 Note: Examples of open, public networks include but are not limited to the Internet; wireless technologies, including 802.11 and Bluetooth; cellular technologies, for example, Global System for Mobile communications (GSM), Code division multiple access (CDMA); and General Packet Radio Service (GPRS).

Name: Trusted Keys
Description: Only trusted keys and/or certificates shall be accepted.

Name: Security Protocols
Description: Security protocols shall be implemented to use only secure configurations, and to not support insecure versions or configurations.

Name: Encryption Strength
Description: The proper encryption strength shall be implemented for the encryption methodology in use (check vendor recommendations/best practices).

Name: TLS Enabled
Description:
For TLS implementations, TLS shall be enabled whenever cardholder data is transmitted or received: 

For example, for browser-based implementations: 
 - "HTTPS" appears as the browser Universal Record Locator (URL) protocol, and 
 - Cardholder data is only requested if "HTTPS" appears as part of the URL.

Name: Best Practices to Implement Strong Encryption
Description: Industry best practices shall be used to implement strong encryption for authentication and transmission for wireless networks transmitting cardholder data or connected to the cardholder data environment.

Name: PANs Rendered Unreadable
Description: PANs shall be rendered unreadable or secured with strong cryptography whenever they are sent via end-user messaging technologies (for example, e-mail, instant messaging, SMS, chat, etc.).

Name: Never Send Unprotected PANs
Description: Policies shall be place that state that unprotected PANs are not to be sent via end-user messaging technologies.

Name: Cardholder Data Transmission Security Policies and Procedures
Description:
Security policies and operational procedures for encrypting transmissions of cardholder data shall be: 
 
 - Documented 
 - In use 
 - Known to all affected parties.

Name: Deploy Anti-virus software
Description: Anti-virus software shall be deployed on all systems commonly affected by malicious software.

Name: Ensure Anti-virus is Capable and Adequate
Description: Anti-virus programs shall be capable of detecting, removing, and protecting against all known types of malicious software (for example, viruses, Trojans, worms, spyware, adware, and rootkits).

Name: Evaluate Low Risk Systems
Description: Periodic evaluations shall be performed to identify and evaluate evolving malware threats in order to confirm whether those systems considered to not be commonly affected by malicious software continue as such.

Name: Maintain Anti-virus
Description:
All anti-virus mechanisms shall be maintained as follows: 
All anti-virus software and definitions shall be kept current.

Name: Automatic Updates
Description:
All anti-virus mechanisms shall be maintained as follows: 
Automatic updates and periodic scans shall be enabled and be performed.

Name: Audit Logs
Description:
All anti-virus mechanisms shall be maintained as follows: 
All anti-virus mechanisms shall be generating audit logs, and logs shall be retained in accordance with PCI DSS Requirement 10.7

Name: Anti-virus Assurance
Description:
All anti-virus mechanisms shall be: 
 
 - Actively running
 - Unable to be disabled or altered by users
 
 Note: Anti-virus solutions may be temporarily disabled only if there is legitimate technical need, as authorized by management on a case-by-case basis. If anti-virus protection needs to be disabled for a specific purpose, it must be formally authorized. Additional security  measures may also need to be implemented for the period of time during which anti-virus protection is not active.

Name: Malware Security Policies and Procedures
Description:
Security policies and operational procedures for protecting systems against malware shall be: 
 
 - Documented 
 - In use 
 - Known to all affected parties.

Name: Identify Security Vulnerabilities
Description:
A process to identify security vulnerabilities, shall include the following: 
 
 - Using reputable outside sources for vulnerability information
 - Assigning a risk ranking to vulnerabilities that includes identification of all "high" risk and "critical" vulnerabilities
 
 Note: Risk rankings should be based on industry best practices as well as consideration of potential impact. For example, criteria for ranking vulnerabilities may include consideration of the CVSS base score and/or the classification by the vendor, and/or type of systems affected. 
 
 Methods for evaluating vulnerabilities and assigning risk ratings will vary based on an organization's environment and risk assessment strategy. Risk rankings should, at a minimum, identify all vulnerabilities considered to  be a "high risk" to the environment. In addition to the risk ranking, vulnerabilities may be considered "critical" if they pose an imminent threat to the environment, impact critical systems, and/or would result in a potential compromise if not addressed. Examples of critical systems may include security systems, public-facing devices and systems, databases, and other systems that store, process or transmit cardholder data.

Name: System and Software Protection
Description: All system components and software shall be protected from known vulnerabilities by installing applicable vendor-supplied security patches.

Name: Critical Security Patches
Description:
Critical security patches shall be installed within one month of release. 
 
 Note: Critical security patches should be identified according to the risk ranking process defined in Requirement 6.1.

Name: Development Based on Industry Standards
Description: Software- development processes shall be based on industry standards and/or best practices.

Name: Software Development Life Cycle
Description: Information security shall be included throughout the software-development life cycle.

Name: Developed in Accordance with PCI DSS
Description: Software applications shall be developed in accordance with PCI DSS (for example, secure authentication and logging).

Name: Development Credentials Removed Prior to Becoming Active
Description:
Software development processes shall ensure the following: 
Development, test, and/or custom application accounts, user IDs, and passwords shall be removed before applications become active or are released to customers.

Name: Custom Code Review
Description:
Software development processes shall ensure the following: 
All custom code shall be reviewed prior to release to production or customers to identify any potential coding vulnerability (using either manual or automated processes as follows: 
 
 - Are code changes reviewed by individuals other than the originating code author, and by individuals who are knowledgeable about code review techniques and secure coding practices? 
 - Do code reviews ensure code is developed according to secure coding guidelines? 
 - Are appropriate corrections are implemented prior to release? 
 - Are code review results are reviewed and approved by management prior to release? 
 
 Note: This requirement for code reviews applies to all custom code (both internal and public-facing), as part of the system development life cycle. Code reviews can be conducted by knowledgeable internal personnel or  third parties. Public-facing web applications are also subject to additional controls, to address ongoing threats and vulnerabilities after implementation, as defined at PCI DSS Requirement 6.6.

Name: Development Environment Separate from Production
Description:
Change control processes and procedures shall be followed for all changes to system components to include the following: 
Development/test environments shall be separate from the production environment.

Name: Access Control in Place
Description:
Change control processes and procedures shall be followed for all changes to system components to include the following: 
Access control shall be in place to enforce the separation between the development/test environments and the production environment.

Name: Separation of Duties
Description: Separation of duties between personnel shall be assigned to the development/test environments and those assigned to the production environment.

Name: Production Data Not Used for Testing
Description: Production data (live PANs) shall not be used for testing or development.

Name: Test Accounts Removed
Description: Test data and accounts shall be removed from system components before the system becomes active / goes into production.

Name: Scope of Change Control Procedures - Documentation
Description:
Change-control procedures shall be documented and shall require the following: 
 
 - Documentation of impact 
 - Documented change control approval by authorized parties 
 - Functionality testing to verify that the change does not adversely impact the security of the system 
 - Back-out procedures

Name: Impact Documentation
Description:
The following shall be performed and documented for all changes: 
Documentation of impact

Name: Documented Approval
Description:
The following shall be performed and documented for all changes: 
Documented approval by authorized parties.

Name: Functionality Testing
Description:
The following shall be performed and documented for all changes: 
Functionality testing to verify that the change does not adversely impact the security of the system.

Name: Compliance with PCI DSS Requirement 6.5
Description:
The following shall be performed and documented for all changes: 
For custom code changes, testing of updates for compliance with PCI DSS Requirement 6.5 before being deployed into production.

Name: Back-out Procedures
Description:
The following shall be performed and documented for all changes: 
Back-out procedures

Name: PCI DSS Requirements Implemented
Description: Upon completion of a significant change, all relevant PCI DSS requirements shall be implemented on all new or changed systems and networks, and documentation updated as applicable.

Name: Coding Vulnerabilities
Description: Software-development processes shall address common coding vulnerabilities.

Name: Developers Trained Annually
Description: Developers shall be trained at least annually in up-to-date secure coding techniques, including how to avoid common coding vulnerabilities.

Name: Address Injection Flaws
Description:
Applications shall be developed based on secure coding guidelines to protect applications from, at a minimum, the following vulnerabilities: 
Coding techniques shall address injection flaws, particularly SQL injection.
 
 Note: Also consider OS Command Injection, LDAP and XPath injection flaws as well as other injection flaws 
 
 Note: The vulnerabilities listed at 6.5.1 through 6.5.10 were current with industry best practices when this version of PCI DSS was published. However, as industry best practices for vulnerability management are updated (for example, the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) Guide, SANS CWE Top 25, CERT Secure Coding, etc.), the current best practices must be used for these requirements.

Name: Address Buffer Overflow
Description:
Applications shall be developed based on secure coding guidelines to protect applications from, at a minimum, the following vulnerabilities: 
Coding techniques shall address buffer overflow vulnerabilities. 
 
 Note: The vulnerabilities listed at 6.5.1 through 6.5.10 were current with industry best practices when this version of PCI DSS was published. However, as industry best practices for vulnerability management are updated (for example, the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) Guide, SANS CWE Top 25, CERT Secure Coding, etc.), the current best practices must be used for these requirements.

Name: Address Insecure Cryptographic Storage
Description:
Applications shall be developed based on secure coding guidelines to protect applications from, at a minimum, the following vulnerabilities: 
Coding techniques shall address insecure cryptographic storage.
 
 Note: The vulnerabilities listed at 6.5.1 through 6.5.10 were current with industry best practices when this version of PCI DSS was published. However, as industry best practices for vulnerability management are updated (for example, the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) Guide, SANS CWE Top 25, CERT Secure Coding, etc.), the current best practices must be used for these requirements.

Name: Address Insecure Communications
Description:
Applications shall be developed based on secure coding guidelines to protect applications from, at a minimum, the following vulnerabilities: 
Coding techniques shall address insecure communications. 
 
 Note: The vulnerabilities listed at 6.5.1 through 6.5.10 were current with industry best practices when this version of PCI DSS was published. However, as industry best practices for vulnerability management are updated (for example, the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) Guide, SANS CWE Top 25, CERT Secure Coding, etc.), the current best practices must be used for these requirements.

Name: Address Improper Error Handling
Description:
Applications shall be developed based on secure coding guidelines to protect applications from, at a minimum, the following vulnerabilities: 
Coding techniques shall address improper error handling. 
 
 Note: The vulnerabilities listed at 6.5.1 through 6.5.10 were current with industry best practices when this version of PCI DSS was published. However, as industry best practices for vulnerability management are updated (for example, the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) Guide, SANS CWE Top 25, CERT Secure Coding, etc.), the current best practices must be used for these requirements.

Name: Address "High Risk" Vulnerabilities
Description:
Applications shall be developed based on secure coding guidelines to protect applications from, at a minimum, the following vulnerabilities: 
Coding techniques shall address all "high risk" vulnerabilities identified in the vulnerability identification process (as defined in PCI DSS Requirement 6.1). 
 
 Note: The vulnerabilities listed at 6.5.1 through 6.5.10 were current with industry best practices when this version of PCI DSS was published. However, as industry best practices for vulnerability management are updated (for example, the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) Guide, SANS CWE Top 25, CERT Secure Coding, etc.), the current best practices must be used for these requirements.

Name: Address Cross-Site Scripting Vulnerabilities
Description:
For web applications and application interfaces (internal or external), applications shall be developed based on secure coding guidelines to protect applications from the following additional vulnerabilities: 
Coding techniques shall address cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities.

Name: Address Improper Access Controls
Description:
For web applications and application interfaces (internal or external), applications shall be developed based on secure coding guidelines to protect applications from the following additional vulnerabilities: 
Coding techniques shall address improper access control such as insecure direct object references, failure to restrict URL access, directory traversal, and failure to restrict user access to functions.

Name: Address Cross-Site Request Forgery
Description:
For web applications and application interfaces (internal or external), applications shall be developed based on secure coding guidelines to protect applications from the following additional vulnerabilities: 
Coding techniques shall address cross-site request forgery (CSRF).

Name: Address Broken Authentication and Session Management
Description:
For web applications and application interfaces (internal or external), applications shall be developed based on secure coding guidelines to protect applications from the following additional vulnerabilities: 
Coding techniques shall address broken authentication and session management.

Name: Periodic Evaluation of Security - Public Facing Web Applications
Description:
For public-facing web applications, new threats and vulnerabilities shall be addressed on an ongoing basis, and these applications shall be protected against known attacks by applying either of the following methods. 
 
 Reviewing public-facing web applications via manual or automated application vulnerability security assessment tools or methods, as follows: 
 - At least annually 
 - After any changes 
 - By an organization that specializes in application security 
 - That, at a minimum, all vulnerabilities in Requirement 6.5 are included in the assessment 
 - That all vulnerabilities are corrected 
 - That the application is re-evaluated after the corrections 
 
 Note: This assessment is not the same as the vulnerability scans performed for Requirement 11.2. 
 
 -- OR -- 
 
 Installing an automated technical solution that detects and prevents web-based attacks (for example, a web-application firewall) as follows: 
 - Is situated in front of public-facing web applications to detect and prevent web-based attacks. 
 - Is actively running and up to date as applicable. 
 - Is generating audit logs. 
 - Is configured to either block web-based attacks, or generate an alert that is immediately investigated.

Name: Security Policies and Procedures for Secure Systems and Applications
Description:
Security policies and operational procedures for developing and maintaining secure systems and applications shall be: 
 
 - Documented 
 - In use 
 - Known to all affected parties.

Name: Limit access based on job function
Description:
Access to system components and cardholder data shall be limited to only those individuals whose jobs require such access, as follows: 
A written policy for access control that incorporates the following: 
 
 - Defining access needs and privilege assignments for each role 
 - Restriction of access to privileged user IDs to least privileges necessary to perform job responsibilities, 
 - Assignment of access based on individual personnels job classification and function 
 - Documented approval (electronically or in writing) by authorized parties for all access, including listing of specific privileges approved

Name: Roles Defined
Description:
Access needs for each role shall be defined, including: 
 
 - System components and data resources that each role needs to access for their job function
 - Level of privilege required (for example, user, administrator, etc.) for accessing resources

Name: Principle of Least Privilege
Description:
Access to privileged user IDs shall be restricted as follows: 
 
 - To least privileges necessary to perform job responsibilities
 - Assigned only to roles that specifically require that privileged access

Name: Privileges should be limited to job function
Description: Access shall be assigned based on individual personnels job classification and function.

Name: Document Required Privilege Approvals
Description: Documented approval by authorized parties shall be required, specifying required privileges.

Name: Access Control System on All Components
Description: An access control system(s) shall be in place for system components to restrict access based on a user's need to know.

Name: Enforce Privileges Based on Job Classifications
Description:
An access control system(s) shall be in place for system components to restrict access based on a user's need to know, and is it set to "deny all" unless specifically allowed, as follows: 
The access control system(s) shall be configured to enforce privileges assigned to individuals based on job classification and function.

Name: Default Deny All Setting
Description:
An access control system(s) shall be in place for system components to restrict access based on a user's need to know, and is it set to "deny all" unless specifically allowed, as follows: 
The access control system(s) shall have a default "deny-all" setting.

Name: Security Policies and Procedures for Restricting Access
Description:
Security policies and operational procedures for restricting access to cardholder data shall be: 
 
 - Documented 
 - In use 
 - Known to all affected parties.

Name: Unique IDs
Description:
Policies and procedures for user identification management controls shall be defined and be in place for nonconsumer users and administrators on all system components, as follows: 
All users shall be assigned a unique ID before allowing them to access system components or cardholder data.

Name: Control Addition, Deletion, and Modification of Accounts
Description:
Policies and procedures for user identification management controls shall be defined and be in place for nonconsumer users and administrators on all system components, as follows: 
Additions, deletions, and modifications of user IDs, credentials, and other identifier objects shall be controlled such that user IDs are implemented only as authorized (including with specified privileges).

Name: Revoke Access for Terminated Users
Description:
Policies and procedures for user identification management controls shall be defined and be in place for nonconsumer users and administrators on all system components, as follows: 
Access for any terminated users shall be immediately deactivated or removed.

Name: Remove Inactive Accounts
Description:
Policies and procedures for user identification management controls shall be defined and be in place for nonconsumer users and administrators on all system components, as follows: 
Inactive user accounts shall either be removed or disabled within 90 days.

Name: Monitor Third Parties Remote Accounts
Description:
Policies and procedures for user identification management controls shall be defined and be in place for nonconsumer users and administrators on all system components, as follows: 
Accounts shall be used by third parties to access, support, or maintain system components via remote access enabled only during the time period needed and disabled when not in use.

Name: Monitor Third Parties Remote Accounts - In Use
Description:
Policies and procedures for user identification management controls shall be defined and be in place for nonconsumer users and administrators on all system components, as follows:  
Third-party remote access accounts shall be monitored when in use.

Name: Limit Failed Access Attempts
Description:
Policies and procedures for user identification management controls shall be defined and be in place for nonconsumer users and administrators on all system components, as follows: 
Repeated access attempts shall be limited by locking out the user ID after no more than six attempts.

Name: Non-consumer Customer Passwords Locked Out for Failed Log-in Attempts
Description:
Policies and procedures for user identification management controls shall be defined and be in place for nonconsumer users and administrators on all system components, as follows: 
Non-consumer/customer passwords shall be temporarily locked-out after not more than six invalid access attempts. (For service providers only)

Name: Account Lockout Duration
Description:
Policies and procedures for user identification management controls shall be defined and be in place for nonconsumer users and administrators on all system components, as follows: 
Once a user account is locked out, the lockout duration shall be set to a minimum of 30 minutes or until an administrator enables the user ID.

Name: Timeouts and Reauthentication
Description:
Policies and procedures for user identification management controls shall be defined and be in place for nonconsumer users and administrators on all system components, as follows: 
If session has been idle for more than 15 minutes, users shall be required to re-authenticate (for example, re-enter the password) to re-activate the terminal or session.

Name: Authentication Methods
Description:
In addition to assigning a unique ID, one or more of the following methods shall be employed to authenticate all users: 
 
 - Something you know, such as a password or passphrase 
 - Something you have, such as a token device or smart card 
 - Something you are, such as a biometric

Name: Store and Transmit Passwords Securely
Description: Strong cryptography shall be used to render all authentication credentials (such as passwords/phrases) unreadable during transmission and storage on all system components.

Name: Strong Encryption
Description: Strong cryptography shall be used to render all non-consumer customers authentication credentials (such as passwords/passphrases) unreadable during transmission and storage on all system components. (For service providers only)

Name: Identify User Before Authentication Tasks
Description: User identity shall be verified before modifying any authentication credential (for example, performing password resets, provisioning new tokens, or generating new keys).

Name: Password Requirements
Description:
User password parameters shall be configured to require passwords/passphrases meet the following:
 
 - A minimum password length of at least seven characters 
 - Contain both numeric and alphabetic characters 
 
 Alternatively, the passwords/passphrases must have complexity and strength at least equivalent to the parameters specified above.

Name: Non-consumer Customer Password Parameters
Description:
Non-consumer customer passwords shall be required to meet the following minimum length and complexity requirements: (For service providers only)
 
 - A minimum password length of at least seven characters 
 - Contain both numeric and alphabetic characters

Name: Change User Passwords Every 90 Days
Description: User passwords/passphrases shall be changed at least every 90 days.

Name: Non-consumer Customer Password Expiration
Description: Non-consumer customer passwords shall be required to be changed periodically, and are non-consumer customers given guidance as to when, and under what circumstances, passwords must change. (For service providers only)

Name: Password reuse requirements
Description: An individual shall submit a new password/phrase that is different from any of the last four passwords/passphrases he or she has used.

Name: Non-consumer Customer Password Reuse
Description: New, non-consumer customer passwords shall be required to be different from any of the last four passwords used. (For new service providers only)

Name: First Time Passwords and Password Resets
Description: Passwords/passphrases shall be set to a unique value for each user for first-time use and upon reset, and each user must change their password immediately after the first use.

Name: Multi-Factor Authentication for Administrative Access to CDE
Description:
All individual non-console administrative access and all remote access to the CDE shall be secured using multi-factor authentication, as follows: 
Multi-factor authentication shall be incorporated for all nonconsole access into the CDE for personnel with administrative access. 
 
 Note: Multi-factor authentication requires that a minimum of two of the three authentication methods (see PCI DSS Requirement 8.2 for descriptions of authentication methods) be used for authentication. Using one factor twice (for example, using two separate passwords) is not considered multi-factor authentication.

Name: Multi-Factor Authentication for Remote Access
Description:
All individual non-console administrative access and all remote access to the CDE shall be secured using multi-factor authentication, as follows: 
Multi-factor authentication shall be incorporated for all remote network access (both user and administrator, and including third-party access for support or maintenance) originating from outside the entity's network. 
 
 Note: Multi-factor authentication requires that a minimum of two of the three authentication methods (see PCI DSS Requirement 8.2 for descriptions of authentication methods) be used for authentication. Using one factor twice (for example, using two separate passwords) is not considered multi-factor authentication.

Name: Communicate Policies and Procedures to End Users
Description: Authentication policies and procedures shall be documented and communicated to all users.

Name: Communicate Policies and Procedures to End Users - Checklist
Description:
Authentication policies and procedures shall include the following: 
 
 - Guidance on selecting strong authentication credentials 
 - Guidance for how users should protect their authentication credentials 
 - Instructions not to reuse previously used passwords 
 - Instructions that users should change passwords if there is any suspicion the password could be compromised

Name: Do Not Use Shared Accounts
Description:
Group, shared, or generic accounts, passwords, or other authentication methods shall be prohibited as follows: 
 
 - Generic user IDs and accounts are disabled or removed; 
 - Shared user IDs for system administration activities and other critical functions do not exist; and 
 - Shared and generic user IDs are not used to administer any system components.

Name: Remote Access to Customers
Description:
Service providers with remote access to customer premises (for example, for support of POS systems or servers) shall use a unique authentication credential (such as a password/passphrase) for each customer. (For service providers only) 
 
 Note: This requirement is not intended to apply to shared hosting providers accessing their own hosting environment, where multiple customer environments are hosted.

Name: Alternative Authentication Mechanisms
Description:
Where other authentication mechanisms are used (for example, physical or logical security tokens, smart cards, and certificates, etc.), the use of these mechanisms shall be assigned as follows: 
 
 - Authentication mechanisms must be assigned to an individual account and not shared among multiple accounts 
 - Physical and/or logical controls must be in place to ensure only the intended account can use that mechanism to gain access

Name: Programmatic Methods
Description:
All access to any database containing cardholder data (including access by applications, administrators, and all other users) shall be restricted as follows: 
All user access to, user queries of, and user actions on (for example, move, copy, delete), the database through programmatic methods only (for example, through stored procedures).

Name: Restricted to Database Administrators
Description:
All access to any database containing cardholder data (including access by applications, administrators, and all other users) shall be restricted as follows: 
User direct access to or queries to of databases restricted to database administrators.

Name: Application IDs
Description:
All access to any database containing cardholder data (including access by applications, administrators, and all other users) shall be restricted as follows: 
Application IDs shall only be able to be used by the applications (and not by individual users or other processes).

Name: Security Policies and Procedures for Identification and Authentication
Description:
Security policies and operational procedures for identification and authentication shall be: 
 
 - Documented 
 - In use 
 - Known to all affected parties.

Name: Facility Entry Controls
Description: Appropriate facility entry controls shall be in place to limit and monitor physical access to systems in the cardholder data environment.

Name: Monitor Physical Access
Description:
Either video cameras or access control mechanisms (or both) shall be in place to monitor individual physical access to sensitive areas.
 
 Note: "Sensitive areas" refers to any data center, server room, or any area that houses systems that store, process, or transmit cardholder data. This excludes public-facing areas where only point-of-sale terminals are present such as the cashier areas in a retail store.

Name: Protected from Tampering or Disabling
Description: Either video cameras or access control mechanisms (or both) shall be protected from tampering or disabling.

Name: Reviewed and Correlated
Description: Data collected from video cameras and/or access control mechanisms shall be reviewed and correlated with other entries.

Name: Storage
Description: Data collected from video cameras and/or access control mechanisms shall be stored for at least three months unless otherwise restricted by law.

Name: Restrict Access to Publicly Accessible Network Jacks
Description:
Physical and/or logical controls shall be in place to restrict access to publicly accessible network jacks. 
 
 For example, network jacks located in public areas and areas accessible to visitors could be disabled and only enabled when network access is explicitly authorized. Alternatively, processes could be implemented to ensure that visitors are escorted at all times in areas with active network jacks.

Name: Access Points Restricted
Description: Physical access to wireless access points, gateways, handheld devices, networking/communications hardware, and telecommunication lines shall be restricted.

Name: Procedures for Distinguishing Between Onsite Personnel and Visitors
Description:
Procedures shall be developed to easily distinguish between onsite personnel and visitors, which include: 
 
 - Identifying onsite personnel and visitors (for example, assigning badges), 
 - Changing access requirements, and 
 - Revoking terminated onsite personnel and expired visitor identification (such as ID badges) 
 
 For the purposes of Requirement 9, "onsite personnel" refers to full-time and part-time employees, temporary employees, contractors and consultants who are physically present on the entity's premises. A

Name: Identification Methods
Description: Identification methods (such as ID badges) shall clearly identify visitors and easily distinguish between onsite personnel and visitors.

Name: Badge System for Authorized Personnel
Description: Access to the badge system shall be limited to authorized personnel.

Name: Sensitive Areas Controlled
Description:
Physical access to sensitive areas shall be controlled for onsite personnel, as follows: 
 
 - Is access authorized and based on individual job function
 - Is access revoked immediately upon termination
 - Upon termination, are all physical access mechanisms, such as keys, access cards, etc., returned or disabled

Name: Visitor Authorizations
Description:
Visitor identification and access shall be handled as follows: 
Visitors shall be authorized before entering, and escorted at all times within, areas where cardholder data is processed or maintained.

Name: Visitor Identification
Description:
Visitor identification and access shall be handled as follows: 
Visitors shall be identified and given a badge or other identification that visibly distinguishes the visitors from onsite personnel.

Name: Badge Expiration
Description:
Visitor identification and access shall be handled as follows: 
Visitor badges or other identification shall expire.

Name: Visitors Asked to Surrender Badge Upon Expiration
Description:
Visitor identification and access shall be handled as follows: 
Visitors shall be asked to surrender the badge or other identification before leaving the facility or at the date of expiration.

Name: Visitor Log
Description:
Visitor identification and access shall be handled as follows:  
A visitor log shall be in use to record physical access to the facility as well as for computer rooms and data centers where cardholder data is stored or transmitted.

Name: Visitor Log Criteria
Description:
Visitor identification and access shall be handled as follows: 
The visitor log shall contain the visitor's name, the firm represented, and the onsite personnel authorizing physical access.

Name: Visitor Log Retention
Description:
Visitor identification and access shall be handled as follows: 
The visitor log shall be retained for at least three months.

Name: Media Physically Secured
Description:
All media shall be physically secured (including but not limited to computers, removable electronic media, paper receipts, paper reports, and faxes). 
 
 For purposes of Requirement 9, "media" refers to all paper and electronic media containing cardholder data.

Name: Media Back-up Storage
Description: The location where media back-ups are stored shall be reviewed at least annually to confirm storage is secure.

Name: Control Over Media Distribution
Description: Strict control shall be maintained over the internal or external distribution of any kind of media.

Name: Media Classification
Description:
Controls shall include the following: 
Media shall be classified so the sensitivity of the data can be determined.

Name: Media Transport
Description:
Controls shall include the following: 
media sent by secured courier or other delivery method that can be accurately tracked.

Name: Management Approval for Transportation
Description:
Controls shall include the following: 
Management approval shall be obtained prior to moving the media (especially when media is distributed to individuals).

Name: Media Storage and Accessibility
Description: Strict control shall be maintained over the storage and accessibility of media.

Name: Inventory of Media
Description: Inventory logs of all media shall be properly maintained.

Name: Periodic Media Inventories Annually
Description: Periodic media inventories shall be conducted at least annually.

Name: Media Destruction
Description: All media shall be destroyed when it is no longer needed for business or legal reasons.

Name: Media Storage Containers
Description:
There shall be a periodic media destruction policy that defines requirements for the following: 
 
 - Hard-copy materials must be crosscut shredded, incinerated, or pulped such that there is reasonable assurance the hard-copy materials cannot be reconstructed. 
 - Storage containers used for materials that are to be destroyed must be secured. 
 - Cardholder data on electronic media must be rendered unrecoverable (e.g., via a secure wipe program in accordance with industry-accepted standards for secure deletion, or by physically destroying the media).

Name: Media Destruction - Hardcopy Materials
Description:
Media destruction shall be performed as follows: 
Hardcopy materials shall be cross-cut shredded, incinerated, or pulped so that cardholder data cannot be reconstructed.

Name: Media Destruction - Storage Containers
Description:
Media destruction shall be performed as follows: 
Storage containers shall be used for materials that contain information to be destroyed secured to prevent access to the contents.

Name: Electronic Media Rendered Unrecoverable
Description: Cardholder data on electronic media shall be rendered unrecoverable (e.g. via a secure wipe program in accordance with industry-accepted standards for secure deletion, or otherwise by physically destroying the media), so that cardholder data cannot be reconstructed.

Name: List of Devices
Description:
Devices that capture payment card data via direct physical interaction with the card shall be protected against tampering and substitution as follows: 
Policies and procedures shall require that a list of such devices be maintained.  
 
Note: This requirement applies to card-reading devices used in card-present transactions (that is, card swipe or dip) at the point of sale. This requirement is not intended to apply to manual key-entry components such as computer keyboards and POS keypads.

Name: Periodically Inspected
Description:
Devices that capture payment card data via direct physical interaction with the card shall be protected against tampering and substitution as follows: 
Policies and procedures shall require that devices are periodically inspected to look for tampering or substitution.  
 
 Note: This requirement applies to card-reading devices used in card-present transactions (that is, card swipe or dip) at the point of sale. This requirement is not intended to apply to manual key-entry components such as computer keyboards and POS keypads.

Name: Personnel Trained
Description:
Devices that capture payment card data via direct physical interaction with the card shall be protected against tampering and substitution as follows: 
Policies and procedures shall require that personnel are trained to be aware of suspicious behavior and to report tampering or substitution of devices. 
 
 Note: This requirement applies to card-reading devices used in card-present transactions (that is, card swipe or dip) at the point of sale. This requirement is not intended to apply to manual key-entry components such as computer keyboards and POS keypads.

Name: Inventory
Description:
The list of devices shall include the following:
 
 - Make, model of device 
 - Location of device (for example, the address of the site or facility where the device is located) 
 - Device serial number or other method of unique identification

Name: Accurate and Up-to-Date
Description: The device list shall be accurate and up to date.

Name: Updated when Added, Relocated, or Decommissioned
Description: The list of devices shall be updated when devices are added, relocated, decommissioned, etc.

Name: Device Surfaces Inspected
Description:
Device surfaces shall be periodically inspected to detect tampering (for example, addition of card skimmers to devices), or substitution (for example, by checking the serial number or other device characteristics to verify it has not been swapped with a fraudulent device) as follows.
 
 Note: Examples of signs that a device might have been tampered with or substituted include unexpected attachments or cables plugged into the device, missing or changed security labels, broken or differently colored casing, or changes to the serial number or other external markings.

Name: Personnel Aware of Procedures for Inspections
Description: Personnel shall be aware of procedures for inspecting devices.

Name: Training Topics
Description:
Personnel shall be trained to be aware of attempted tampering or replacement of devices, to include the following: Do training materials for personnel at point-of-sale locations include the following:

 - Verify the identity of any third-party persons claiming to be repair or maintenance personnel, prior to granting them access to modify or troubleshoot devices. 
 - Do not install, replace, or return devices without verification. 
 - Be aware of suspicious behavior around devices (for example, attempts by unknown persons to unplug or open devices). 
 - Report suspicious behavior and indications of device tampering or substitution to appropriate personnel (for example, to a manager or security officer).

Name: Point-of-Sale Location Trainings on Detecting and Reporting Attempted Tampering
Description:
Personnel shall be trained to be aware of attempted tampering or replacement of devices, to include the following: 
Personnel at point-of-sale locations shall have received training, and shall be aware of procedures to detect and report attempted tampering or replacement of devices.

Name: Restricting Physical Access Policies and Procedures
Description:
Security policies and operational procedures for restricting physical access to cardholder data shall be: 
 
 - Documented 
 - In use 
 - Known to all affected parties.

Name: Audit Trails Enabled
Description: Audit trails shall be enabled and active for system components.

Name: System Components Linked to Users
Description: Access to system components shall be linked to individual users.

Name: Auditable Event - Individual User Access Cardholder Data
Description:
Automated audit trails shall be implemented for all system components to reconstruct the following events: 
All individual user accesses to cardholder data.

Name: Auditable Event - Actions by Admins
Description:
Automated audit trails shall be implemented for all system components to reconstruct the following events: 
All actions taken by any individual with root or administrative privileges.

Name: Auditable Event - Access to Audit Trails
Description:
Automated audit trails shall be implemented for all system components to reconstruct the following events: 
Access to all audit trails.

Name: Auditable Event - Invalid Access Attempts
Description:
Automated audit trails shall be implemented for all system components to reconstruct the following events: 
Invalid logical access attempts.

Name: Auditable Event - Changes to Credentials
Description:
Automated audit trails shall be implemented for all system components to reconstruct the following events: 
Ensure use of and changes to identification and authentication mechanisms, including but not limited to creation of new accounts and elevation of privileges, and all changes, additions, or deletions to accounts with root or administrative privileges.

Name: Auditable Event - Changes to Audit Logs
Description:
Automated audit trails shall be implemented for all system components to reconstruct the following events: 
Initialization, stopping, or pausing of the audit logs.

Name: Auditable Event - Creation and Deletion of System-Level Objects
Description:
Automated audit trails shall be implemented for all system components to reconstruct the following events: 
Creation and deletion of system-level objects.

Name: Audit Trail - User Identification
Description:
The following audit trail entries shall be recorded for all system components for each event: 
User identification.

Name: Audit Trail - Type of event
Description:
The following audit trail entries shall be recorded for all system components for each event: 
Type of event.

Name: Audit Trail - Time of Event
Description:
The following audit trail entries shall be recorded for all system components for each event: 
Date and time.

Name: Audit Trail - Success or Failure
Description:
The following audit trail entries shall be recorded for all system components for each event:
Success or failure indication.

Name: Audit Trail - Origin
Description:
The following audit trail entries shall be recorded for all system components for each event: 
Origination of event.

Name: Audit Trail - System Component
Description:
The following audit trail entries shall be recorded for all system components for each event: 
Identity or name of affected data, system component, or resource.

Name: Use time synchronization across systems
Description:
All critical system clocks and times shall be synchronized through use of time synchronization technology, and is the technology kept current.  
 
 Note: One example of time synchronization technology is Network Time Protocol (NTP).

Name: Time Synchronization - Correct and Consistent Time - IAT or UTC
Description:
The following processes shall be implemented for critical systems to have the correct and consistent time: 
Only designated central time server(s) shall receive time signals from external sources, and time signals from external sources shall be based on International Atomic Time or UTC.

Name: Time Synchronization - Correct and Consistent Time - Peer for Accuracy
Description:
The following processes shall be implemented for critical systems to have the correct and consistent time: 
Where there is more than one designated time server, the time servers shall peer with each other to keep accurate time.

Name: Time Synchronization - Correct and Consistent Time - Designated Servers
Description:
The following processes shall be implemented for critical systems to have the correct and consistent time:
Systems shall receive time only from designated central time server(s).

Name: Time Synchronization - Protect - Restricted
Description:
Time data shall be protected as follows: 
Access to time data shall be restricted to only personnel with a business need to access time data.

Name: Time Synchronization - Protect - Changes Logged
Description:
Time data shall be protected as follows: 
Changes to time settings on critical systems shall be logged, monitored, and reviewed.

Name: Time Synchronization - Sources
Description:
Time settings shall be received from specific, industry-accepted time sources. (This is to prevent a malicious individual from changing the clock). 
 
 Optionally, those updates can be encrypted with a symmetric key, and access control lists can be created that specify the IP addresses of client machines that will be provided with the time updates (to prevent unauthorized use of internal time servers).

Name: Audit Trails - Limit viewing
Description:
Audit trails shall be secured so they cannot be altered, as follows: 
Viewing of audit trails shall be limited to those with a job-related need.

Name: Audit Trails - Protection
Description:
Audit trails shall be secured so they cannot be altered, as follows: 
Audit trail files shall be protected from unauthorized modifications via access control mechanisms, physical segregation, and/or network segregation.

Name: Audit Trails - Backups
Description:
Audit trails shall be secured so they cannot be altered, as follows: 
Audit trail files shall be promptly backed up to a centralized log server or media that is difficult to alter.

Name: Audit Trails - External Devices
Description:
Audit trails shall be secured so they cannot be altered, as follows: 
Logs for external-facing technologies (for example, wireless, firewalls, DNS, mail) shall be written onto a secure, centralized, internal log server or media.

Name: Audit Trails - File Integrity
Description:
